Memory is a strange thing.

A modern home built on the shore with a large deck. The skin of the lake is a cloudy mirror. LOUISE BANKS stares up at the sky, leaning against the de railing. Merlot glass in one hand. Louise has a clean, timeless look about her; the kind of woman who ages gracefully. Short hair.
It doesn’t work like I thought it did. We are so bound by time; by its order. She steps back inside, a little tipsy, smiling.
Stacks of books on shelves and tables. A telescope agains glass wall. And dry-erase boards, marked with foreign languages. Different colors for different dialects.
Maybe there’s a higher order. Mingled here are also dinner plates. Candlelight.

Darling, is there any more wine? She pauses when a deck light winks on outside. Her eyes sparkle when she sees something: A question, written on the glass, lit from outdoors. “Do you want to make a baby?”

I used to think this was the beginning of your story.  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 2. Louise goes right to the glass, wanting to touch the ques with her finger to make sure it’s real. CLOSE ON HER FACE: From outside looking in, a curious circular shadow is thrown from the deck light. But her ey start to water. In the background, the bedroom door hangs open and the silhouette of a MAN leans against the frame, watching her Louise turns around, smiling again. We know her answer.
Louise cradles a NEWBORN GIRL in her arms. Her name: HANN Hannah reaches up. Crooks her tiny hand around Louise's finger.
A NURSE starts to take baby Hannah to give Louise some re Hannah BLEATS and reaches for her mother. Louise smiles through the exhaustion and pulls her back--
Okay, come back, come back to me...
Four-year-old HANNAH dressed as a cowgirl. On a toy riding horse with wheels for hooves. Giggling like she can’t stop.
I remember moments in the middle. She pulls both finger-guns, aimed at us.
Stick ‘em up! INT. HANNAH'S ROOM — NIGHT 5 Eight-year-old Hannah is tucked in bed. Said to us as a prayer:
I love you.  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 3. INT. LAKE HOUSE — NIGHT Twelve-year-old Hannah glowers at us:
I hate you! --and storms into her room.
Twelve-year-old daughter HANNAH lies, eyes closed. Hannah is pale. Her head has been shaved in the last mont

And this was the end. Louise holds her daughter’s hand in hers. Her thumb traces Hannah’s knuckles. A life monitor beeps as Hannah’s heart stops. Hannah’s eyes roll up and she sighs her final breath. Louise’s grip on her daughter tightens. Trembling. A Nurse starts to pull Louise away, but she hangs on-- no it’s mother trying to return to her baby girl--
Come back-- come back to me, baby-- Louise is unaware she’s crying. Hannah remains motionless
But now I’m not so sure I believe in beginnings and endings. There are days that define your story beyond your life. CUT TO BLACK.
Like the day they arrived.
Storybook blue, patched with cumulous clouds. Drifting down to find a tree line in motion. Looking into a car on a road.  10 iL 12 Yellow (06/11/2015) 4.

Louise parks her car end steps out. Her hair is longer he and there’s no wedding band on her finger. She carries herself like someone who’s learned how to be alone, handling her briefcase, coffee, keys, etc. It’s oddly quiet in the garage around her. EXT. UNIVERSITY CAMPUS — DAY 10 Louise crosses campus. Absorbed in her thoughts. Overhead, a pair of F-22 fighters slice across the sky. EXT. STUDENT CENTER - MOMENTS LATER 1i Louise passes the campus center. A crowd of STUDENTS are huddled around the glass outside student center, looking in at a large TV. The crowd is to dense for Louise to see what is on the TV. Louise frowns, but keeps going. Overhead, a second pair of fighter jets rocket past. Louise looks up at the sky. Apprehensive. INT. UNIVERSITY CLASSROOM — DAY 12 Louise enters a classroom, leaving the door open behind h Out in the hall, a couple of STUDENTS run by, but it’s unclear if they’re late for class or it’s something worse Louise steps to her desk to unload her briefcase and ther The course name is written on the blackboard behind the d “Advanced Linguistics” and “Dr. Louise Banks.”

Good morning, everyone. No response. Louise finally looks to the class to discove Only FOUR STUDENTS seated in an otherwise empty classroom LOUISE (CONT’D) Where is everyone?  Pink (05/18/2015) 5. The Grad Students in the room shrug. These are the hardco learners, with their laptops out and textbooks open. The class session BELL chimes over the PA. Louise looks b at the door, silently considering something, then decides LOUISE (CONT’D) Well, let’s get started. Today we're talking about Portuguese, and why it sounds so different from the other Romance languages. Louise walks to a MAP of western Europe on a rolling ease parked next to a TV.

The story of Portuguese begins with the Kingdom of Galicia, in the middle ages, where the language was seen as an expression of art. The way it was written and spoken was rooted in aesthetics. One Grad Student’s phone CHIMES with an alert. Louise pau thinking what the other Students are thinking--
Any news you want to share? The Student reading his phone frowns, suddenly nervous.

Uhh, Doctor Banks? Can you turn on the TV to a news channel? Louise grabs her TV remote and turns the set to CNN, to reveal AERIAL FOOTAGE from a helicopter, also live, as a REPORTER narrates in a near panic:

Are you seeing this!? Oh dear god what is that noise-- WHAT IS IT-- should we be this close to it?! FOOTAGE shows wilderness, where a STRANGE, OBLONG OBJECT hovers over the tree line. It absorbs sunlight and its dimensions are difficult to grasp -- at times it appears almost concave, poised as if to dig into the planet’s cru Another helicopter edges into view, and suddenly the scal the object is clear: It’s the size of a massive skyscrape Bumper text at the bottom of the screen reads: “STRANGE CRAFT IN MONTANA”  Pink (05/18/2015) 6. Amid the WHUFF of the helicopter, a reporter on location shouting in a voice on verge of a nervous breakdown: The audio cuts out and an ANCHORWOMAN takes over. Cutting the studio where she pulls her attention to the camera:

The object, uh, apparently touched down forty minutes ago just north of I-94, we're, we’re waiting to hear if this is perhaps an experimental vessel or-- She looks for help off-camera and they cut to: MORE FOOTAGE, closer to the ground. The oblong ship is immense. And seemingly without creases or windows.

Hold on, it-- I’m learning that more objects like this have landed in as many as eight other locations around the world. We’re waiting for confirmation-- yes? Can we--? Okay-- New footage: a live feed in Japan. An identical CONCAVE S is parked above a stadium lot.

This is from a site in Hokkaido! The Grad Students all stare in silent horror at the foota One of them stands up and gathers his stuff, ready to lea But he only gets as far as standing up. Unsure what to do next; where to run to.

(panicked) This is worldwide, it is happening right now! We don’t-- do we know where they came from? A campus SIREN spins up; the kind used for tornado warnin The STUDENTS now start to get their materials together, t leave. Louise snaps out of her shock, and with authority:
Okay, yes, let’s go. Class over.  13 14 15 Pink (05/18/2015) 7.

Louise joins a FLOCK of people on campus hurrying to the parking structures. Nearly everyone keeps looking up from time to time. The SIREN is louder here. Above: Another pair of FIGHTER JETS fly overhead. EXT. UNIVERSITY PARKING STRUCTURE — DAY 14 Louise gets to her sedan, climbs inside, windows down. He satellite radio plays as she powers the car --
But for now we’re simply asking for cooperation while authorities assess the object. Until further notice, the site is a no-fly zone. From the street: Sounds of a car accident. It startles he

So you’re saying it’s not ours? Do you know if it’s even from Earth? Louise opens her door and steps out again, to look down a The wreck below. The aftermath. The two DRIVERS panicked on edge but uninjured.
We're still collecting information, coordinating with other nations. We're not the only ones with one of these in our back yard. Louise returns to her car and straps herself in.

If this is some sort of peaceful first contact, why send twelve? Why not just one? She backs out, tires yelping at her quick getaway. EXT. LAKE HOUSE — EVENING 15 Her sedan pulls up at the lake house from the opener.  16 7 18 Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 8. INT. LAKE HOUSE —- FRONT ENTRY - EVENING 16 Louise enters with her cell phone to her ear, carrying he valise.

(into phone) I don’t know, Mom, I’m listening to the same news coverage. (beat) Don’t-- Mom, don’t bother with that channel, how many times do I have to tell you not to pay attention to those idiots? (beat) All right then.
Traversing a hallway to bedrooms. Louise pulls her shoes by the heel, switching hands with the phone as she goes.
Do I sound worried? Exactly. Louise pauses at an open bedroom door halfway down the ha
Me? Oh, you know. The same. There’s a tiredness in her answer. Like she’s been down t road with her mother before.
An empty room, save for a couple of stray book boxes and neglected stationary bike in the corner. Louise surveys the room from the door.

I’m fine, Mom. (not really) Okay, call me later. She disconnects the call and leans against the door frame Staring into the empty room with a quiet sadness. Finally, having come to some decision, she pushes off aga  19 Yellow (06/11/2015) 9. INT. LIVING ROOM — LATER 19 Louise, alone, on the couch. Half a bottle of wine left. The place is furnished nicely, but there are telltale sig of a single occupant in a larger space. No family photos. A recliner by the couch has become a surrogate bookshelf. TV is on. More coverage of the alien landing.

.+--and at around eight hours after landing, there are still no signs of what might be called ‘first contact.’ The objects measure at least fifteen hundred feet tall-- Changing channel. Footage changes to a snowy tundra where another UFO has landed and flattened a section of fence l This is a foreign channel. Louise gets international stations. The anchor speaks in Russian. New channel: Another SHIP, hovering over the ocean. AERIAL COVERAGE: Fleets from three different nations thre each other for possession of the massive UFO.

--none of whom can claim because this ‘object’ as it’s being called is actually hovering over international waters. One Iranian cruiser has fired across the bow of the Indian fleet-- Louise changes the channel. Finding: The press room in the west wing of the White Hou

We have to entertain the idea that, if it is a kind of vessel, it may be unmanned. Regardless, we have a protocol for scenarios like this-- The word “protocol” instantly sours Louise to the news. S mutes the TV and shuffles off to her bedroom--  20 21 22 23 24 Yellow (06/11/2015) 10. INT. LOUISE’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 20 --picks up a remote off a nightstand and turns on a TV fa her bed. More news, the volume low. INT. LOUISE’S BEDROOM —- MORNING 21 Louise is asleep in bed. The covers are a mess. She’s spooning extra pillows as if they were a bedfellow. Louise wakes with a start, as if from a dream. EXT. UNIVERSITY CAMPUS — MORNING 22 Louise returns to work. The campus is empty. Two STUDENTS hurry between buildings Louise passes the student center. It’s too quiet. INT. UNIVERSITY CLASSROOM — MORNING 23 Louise enters her classroom. No one has showed up. INT. LOUISE’S OFFICE - DAY 24 A cramped office with a window looking out on the city. Sirens wail in the distance. Louise has barely decorated the place. It’s the sign of someone untethered from the world. Closed off. She sits a her desk, grading papers. Streaming video news coverage p on her computer.
Forty-eight hours later, and still no further developments from the sites of the twelve UFOs. Borders are closed and flights--

Two days and already the public expects us to know the answers. Louise turns to see the source of the voice at her office door. COLONEL WEBER (50s) wears civilian clothing but his body language screams career military. Callused hands, sh eyes, rigid posture.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 10A. He steps in and reaches to her computer, powering off the speakers. Behind him, two large MEN stand guard in the ha
Who are you?  Yellow (06/11/2015) il. Weber has his I.D. ready; shows it to her.
I’m Colonel G.T. Weber. You and I never formally met but two years ago you did some Farsi translation for Army Intelligence.
I remember. Alan Boudreau hired me.
Alan works for me. You made quick work of those insurgent videos. Louise crosses her arms. He’s touched a nerve.
You made quick work of those insurgents.
You have another two years on your SSBI so you still have top secret clearance. That's why I’m in your office, and not at Berkeley.
Okay...

I need you to translate something for me. As one of the men guarding the door shuts it, giving them total privacy, Colonel Weber places a pocket-sized digita recorder on Louise’s desk. He hits PLAY. White noise, shuffling. Then murmured talk, and: MAN’S VOICE (on recorder) Why are you here? In response: A SERIES OF SOUNDS that have no Earthly comparison. An audio mixture of organic clicks, rushing water, whispers, and low-octave moaning. MAN’S VOICE (CONT’D) (on recorder) Can you understand us?  12. Almost immediately, the SOUNDS return, this time slightly different. The bass tone is lower. The whispers raspy. Louise listens, rapt. As if she’s waking up from a long sleep. She leans in. Weber studies her face while she listens. MAN’S VOICE (CONT’D) (on recorder) Where did you come from? Before an answer is heard, Weber stops playback and takes back the recorder.
Well? What do you make of it?
Is that...
Yes. The weight of his answer settles on Louise. Beat.
How many?
How many what?
How many of them were speaking? Weber raises an eyebrow at her but answers.
Two. Assume they were not speaking at the same time.
Are you sure? Do they have mouths?

Keep your focus on the sounds. Weber replays a portion of the recording. The alien VOICE sounds even stranger a second time. COLONEL WEBER (CONT’D) What would be your approach to translating this? Does any of it sound like words to you? Phrases?  Pink (05/18/2015) 13.
I don’t know.
(said not as a question) What can you tell me.
I can tell you it’s impossible to translate this from an audio file. To do this right, I need to be there. Interacting with them. Weber bristles at this.
You didn’t need that for the Farsi translations.
It was Burushaski, not Farsi, and I didn’t need it because I already knew the language. This-- (points at recorder) This is a whole new ball game.
I know what you’re doing.
Tell me what I’m doing.
I’m not taking you to Montana. It’s all I can do to keep it from becoming a tourist site for anyone with TS clearance.
I’m just telling you what it will take to do this job.
We will set up a safe room at a facility here in town where you can observe video of the conversations in real-time. I’1l put you on the line with our team at the site.
No.  Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 14.
(beat) What do you mean, ‘no’?
It won't work that way.
You’1l make it work. Her patience wears thin.
Have they spoken to us in English?
No.

Have they played back any of our media, or given you any indication they understand us? Weber doesn’t have a reply for this. His eyes shift. LOUISE (CONT’D) So in order for this to work, I might have to teach them English. The basics. Nouns, verbs. I can’t do that remotely. I have to be in the room with them. Weber and Louise stare down.
There is one opportunity here, and that is to study them remotely. If I leave here, your chance is gone. Weber turns to leave.
Colonel... You mentioned Berkeley. You going to ask Danvers next? Weber pauses at the door.
Maybe, why?

Before you commit to him, ask him the Sanskrit word for “war” and its translation.  25 26 Pink (05/18/2015) 15. She grins at him. Weber exits. After he leaves, her grin fades. INT. LOUISE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 25 Louise is asleep in her bed. Again with the formation of pillows around her. She wakes to a rhythmic thumping. Low; dull. Her hand goe her heart. It’s not her heart. From her bedroom window: A distant flying object vaguely a helicopter. One thing is clear: it’s on fast approach. As it gets closer, treetops bend and leaves scatter. INT. LOUISE’S LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER 26 Dressed in a bathrobe, Louise crosses to the front window looking out on her wide, flat front yard. SPOTLIGHTS shine into her house, STROBES pop. We are so u to how a helicopter sounds, but this is different. The en noises, the rotors -- it’s more muscular; threatening. The lights finally dim to reveal: A Sikorsky UH-60 Blackh has touched down on the lawn. The passenger door is open, slid back to reveal someone riding in the rear compartmen Her doorbell rings. Louise answers it. Weber stands at the door, now in military uniform.
Good morning.
Colonel?
Gavisti.
That's the word. But what did Danvers say it means in Sanskrit?
He said it means an argument. What does it really mean?
“BR desire for more cows.”  27
Pack your bags. It hits Louise: She got the job. All right. Give me twenty minutes.

You have ten. Louise glares at Weber for just a moment, then dashes off her bedroom. EXT. LAKE HOUSE —- PRE-DAWN 27 Louise (now dressed and carrying an overnight bag) hurrie for the Blackhawk. The rotor blades flatten the grass on lawn and pull at Louise’s coat. Weber helps Louise inside and then shuts the door. The helicopter rises immediately.
Louise drops into a bench seat still holding her bag. As she buckles in:

Language is the foundation of civilization. Across from her: IAN DONNELLY (late 30s), Oxford shirt, w hair, fierce eyes, and a smile in the corner of his mouth that makes it hard to tell what he’s thinking. Ian holds a book. He’s reading from it.
Pardon?
“It is the glue that holds a people together, and it is the first weapon drawn in a conflict.”
Louise, this is Ian Donnelly. Neither Louise nor Ian offer to shake hands. They study o another as they talk.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 7.
That’s quite a greeting.
You wrote it.
It’s the kind of thing you write as a preface. Dazzle them with basics.
It’s good. Even if it’s wrong.
Wrong?
The cornerstone of civilization isn’t language. It’s science.
Ian is a theoretical physicist from Los Alamos. He is the man with the questions. You will be reporting to me but you’1ll be working with him when you’re in the shell.
The shell?
That’s what they’re calling the UFO.
Priority one: What do they want, where are they from? Weber speaks them as orders. Ian thinks it’s a conversati
Yes, but beyond that: How did they get here? Are they capable of faster-than-light travel? Ian pulls a Moleskine notebook from his pocket, excited t share from it--
I've prepared a list of questions, starting with some “handshake” binary sequences--  28 29 30 Yellow (06/11/2015) 18.
How about we just talk to them first? Before we start throwing math problems at them.
This is why you’re both here. Ian nods as he puts his notebook up, but it’s clear he’s anxious to get past the small talk and on to the big idea

Wide angle on approach. A mile out. Roads and highways ar crowded with traffic, up against military blockades. In the distance: The ALIEN SHIP, in silhouette behind the rising egg-yolk sun. The ship dwarfs the wilderness around it and stands out l a Massive, strange edifice that would seem ancient were i not hovering over the ground. At this distance, a low TONE starts to resonate in everyo sternum. The Blackhawk lances over the treeline.

LOUISE'S POV: The alien ship towers over the field. It se impossibly balanced, as if it could tip over and crush everyone at any time. A mile away, a series of tents have been erected. Up clos the ship looks majestic; ominous.
Louise and Ian stare out the side window at the ship.
Every thirteen hours a sort of door opens up, at the base. That’s where we go in.
How many of us are here?
You're the only scientists going in. But you both have a team here--  31 Yellow (06/11/2015) 19.
A team? What kind of team?
Mostly NSA. Cryptanalysts, a couple of signal processing experts... A phone handset’s cradle lights up by Weber. He answers i
(sotto, to Tan) When’s the next meeting? Ian shrugs -- he just got here. He’s busy making a SKETCH the ship in his notebook. His notebook is a tiny library all his thoughts and ideas. Weber hangs up.
We’ll need to hurry you through.

Colonel Weber, Ian, and Louise are escorted out of the helicopter and into base camp. The camp is divided into t clusters of tents/buildings: OPERATIONS and SCIENCE. CAPTAIN MARKS (barely 30, disciplined; a man of rules) me Weber and updates him as they walk:
Materials team called in with some early analysis.
Tell me.

Normally you find three or four elements in base material. Humans have eleven. That thing is made of every single element known to us plus a dozen we’ve never seen. Weber frowns, worried. But Ian has the opposite reaction: face lights up in wonderment, and a hundred questions pil in his mind but then —-
All right. Take these two to Kettler.  32 33 Yellow (06/11/2015) 20.
Yessir.

(to Ian and Louise) You will follow this man to medical. The procedure should take just a few minutes. Louise and Ian keep up with the Captain’s brisk march. A Medevac helicopter powers up on a pad nearby. Someone i strapped to a gurney inside, flanked by two Paramedics. Ian notices. So does Louise. They exchange looks.
Captain Marks leads them to a large tent. Louise looks back at the ship for a moment. Nervous. Behind her, Ian looks back at it too. Curious.

A staff of military medical personnel are busy testing ne diagnostic equipment. Captain Marks opens a flap into a room where we find a ma scrubs with a tray of hypodermics. This is DR. KETTLER; professorial, even-toned voice, but a predator’s eyes.

Louise Banks and Ian Donnelly? Louise nods. Kettler gestures to two plastic chairs. They sit, while he prepares a syringe with a vial attached. DR. KETTLER (CONT’D) When is the last time either of you have eaten?
Last night.
When is the last time you did something stressful?
Does right now count?
Who was being carted off on the medevac?

Not everyone is wired for what you’re about to do. Our brains aren’t always able to process experiences like this. (then) I’m going to get some blood from you, and give you an immunization dose that covers a battery of bacterial threats. Roll up your sleeves, please. Ian begins rolling up his Oxford shirt sleeve. Louise not Ian is complying, then follows suit. Kettler moves his tray over and wraps a band around Louis arm, just above her elbow. As he draws blood: DR. KETTLER (CONT’D) The booster is a kick to your system, so you might feel some side effects. Nausea. Dizziness. Headaches. A ringing in your ear like you have Tinnitus. Louise looks over at Ian to share a look of: Do you belie what Kettler just said? But Ian is staring out a window at the big ship.

Ian and Louise enter this tent that serves as the nerve center of base camp. The room is fitted with dozens of flatscreens, each one monitoring activity of a landing si in some other part of the world.

Honestly they’ve been mostly quiet so far. And by the time we start to make any real progress, it’s over, and we're out the door again.  Yellow (06/11/2015) 21a, Weber is waiting for them, now in full uniform. Behind hi large white board. AUSTRALIAN SCIENTIST (0.S.) (CONT’D) We're trying to reduce our setup time, maybe limit the diagnostic gear so we can focus more on our friends across the glass.
How long are your sessions?  Pink (05/18/2015) 22. On the white board: Twelve columns, with labels of countr

text: Information is written under the columns, and spy satelli plus location photos are peppered throughout. It shows wh every country is doing at their separate sites. Standing at a MONITOR is a MAN in a suit and tie. Arms crossed over his chest. This is AGENT HALPERN: All busine His job is international relations. On the monitor is an AUSTRALIAN SCIENTIST talking via VTC

The barometer readings don’t change, but like clockwork, after forty-six minutes and two seconds the gravity slowly shifts to slide us out of the room. Like we’re insects on a piece of paper and they’re easing us out of the house.
Is there a scientific explanation for it? Like, is it for them?
We think it’s for us. The air doesn’t seem to circulate in the chamber, so after about an hour we’d run out of oxygen.
But it doesn’t take thirteen hours to pump fresh air into that room.
Atmosphere.
Excuse me?
If their atmosphere is different from Earth, it could take them hours to re-balance the oh-two content and pressure for us every time they open their door.
So, you’re saying they could suffocate us if they wanted.  Pink (05/18/2015) 22a, Weber guides Ian away from Halpern and the monitors, back toward the way out of the tent.
Remember: We need answers as soon as possible. Why they are here. What they want, what they will give us. This is the priority.  35 36 Yellow (06/11/2015) 23.
Have they responded to anything? Numbers? Shapes? Fibonnacci?
We can’t tell what they’re saying when they respond to “hello.” So don’t get ahead of yourselves. Louise frowns as a new question occurs to her.
What have you figured out?

On the other side of basecamp: Communications. Weber pull back the flap and Louise enters, Ian trailing behind her. Inside: A dozen MEN AND WOMEN work at computer stations w large monitors and at an oversized white board. The monit all display the same kind of data: audio recordings, visu bouncing and fluctuating as the alien VOICES speak. Some of the members approach to shake Louise’s hand, and LIB their greetings before returning to analysis work. A few of them remain at their stations, headphones on.
We're just getting started. Stepping back, Louise asks Weber:
Why not send them in?

(beat) Honestly, they all prefer to stay out here. Suddenly, a low, deep bass TONE vibrates the tent. A pen falls off a desk. A TECH grabs his coffee mug. The tent-t CLATTER against the support poles. It’s terrifying. COLONEL WEBER (CONT’D) That’s our ten-minute warning. INT. “CLEAN ROOM” — DAY 36 A miniature Silkwood. Contained showers. Dressing areas.
Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 24. Full HAZMAT suits hang on a wall. Captain Marks brings Ian and Louise in. They each have co swabs taped to their elbows now.
Climb into these. I’ll help you with the helmet seals.
What kind of radiation exposure are we walking into?
Nominal. These are just for safety.
Is there physical contact with the, the-- am I the only one who has trouble saying “aliens”?
No.
There’s a wall. Like a glass wall. You can’t get to them.

What do they look like? A flashing light winks over the exit door. Captain Marks claps his hands: Let’s go. On Louise, wanting to get off this ride, but she follows- EXT. BASE CAMP — DAY A36 The Shell looms in the distance, at the other end of a mi long “road” formed in the grass from all the back-and-for A dusty PICKUP TRUCK waits for them, its tailgate down, a step ladder planted at its lip. A second TRUCK is already on the road, its bed loaded wit gear and two SCIENCE TECHS in similar moonsuits. Nearby, two DRONE OPERATORS launch a surveillance drone i the air, which then flies ahead of the trucks, toward the shell. Leading the way.  37 Blue Draft (05/06/2015) 25. Louise and Ian are led into their pickup truck. Bench sea has been set up, but it all feels a bit cobbled together. Weber (in his suit and mask) nods at a LIEUTENANT who loc the tailgate into place for them and slaps the truck: The good to go. The truck starts for the Shell. Louise stares at it with wide eyes. Soon, the sun eclipse the ship and the whole truck succumbs to shadow. HIGH ANGLE: From a perch above the Shell: the two tiny tr slow as they arrive underneath it. EXT. “THE SHELL” - MOMENTS LATER 37 The craft is even more intimidating close-up. Its surface the undercarriage portion seems to absorb light. It’s also floating twenty or so feet overhead. Louise and Ian join a small contingent of MILITARY PERSON also in HAZMAT suits, all attending crates of specialty g One of them gestures at: A SCISSOR LIFT parked directly under the Shell. Nearby, a second “backup” scissor lift sits parked. She follows Weber, Marks, and two other Science Techs (a total of 6). Her breath is loud in her helmet. She’s shak They step onto the Scissor Lift. Captain Marks pounds a button and they start to elevate. A safety CHAIN hooked to the guard rail on the lift RATTL incessantly. Louise notices it. Looks up again.
It’s just hovering...

They probably traveled millions of light years, they couldn’t go an extra twenty feet? Said with a grin, but no one laughs. The lift is now so close overhead, they can reach up and touch it. The two TECHS do just that -- feeling the surfa for some purchase or change. But it’s so dark, there’s no real sense of dimension here.  38 Yellow (06/11/2015) 26. Ian tries, too. And suddenly they’re all reaching, feelin IAN’S GLOVED HAND curls into something. An edge. A hole t can’t be seen on the surface. It widens, as marked by his hand. Opening like a mouth to accept the lift inside.
Looking down from within the tunnel: Flashlights clack ON among the team, pointed up, seeking a sense of destinatio
Is this how it always goes?

Yes. (beat) This is the easy part. Our job was recon. Now it’s your job. This does nothing to comfort Louise. Above: A distant, indiscernible light. Ian studies the surface of the tunnel as they ascend, mov his flashlight beam over it. In the light’s edge, it seem perfectly smooth, but in the full beam there’s a texture. The lift stops.
